contents.title: Manual metadata
contents.description: manual version, last update time

contents.title: Why we use a lab manual
contents.description: the role it plays in the lab

contents.title: How to update the manual
contents.description: in which case, how, and how regularly you plan to update it

options.text: When changes are made, note the date of the update; note the author of the edits; add any acronyms used to the list of acronyms.

When changes are made, update the metadata to increment the version (use semantic versioning of release.major.minor); note the new date; note the author of the edits; add any acronyms used to the list of acronyms.

contents.title: Abbreviations
contents.description: comprehensive list of abbreviations used in the manual

contents.title: Lab mission/focus
contents.description: what the lab wants to achieve, what are the lab's ambitions / research topics

contents.title: Lab philosophy/values
contents.description: how the lab approaches its work (e.g., following Open Science, consistently questioning one’s own findings, honesty, transparency, inclusion, diversity)

contents.title: Lab history
contents.description: who started it, what has changed since the start, past research interests, notable publications

contents.title: Contact information
contents.description: physical address; email address; website etc.

contents.title: Facilities
contents.description: testing spaces; pictures or referable descriptions of the lab

contents.title: Lab resources
contents.description: inventory with a full description of the instruments, tools, and equipment

contents.title: Lab ethical principles
contents.description: how to respect the rights and personalities of each other; required human subjects training

contents.title: Diversity statement
contents.description: a clear statement that the PI and the lab value diversity and practices that promote inclusiveness (e.g., checking pronouns, accomodations, mutual respect for people with diverse backgrounds and characteristics)

contents.title: Institutional rules and code of conduct
contents.description: list their links

contents.title: Onboarding
contents.description: what to do when joining the lab , it can be a standalone document

contents.title: Online accounts
contents.description: on what services (e.g., GitHub, Slack, GoogleDrive, OSF.io, Dropbox, Twitter, Google Calendar, ORCID profile, Publon profile, Google Scholar profile, ResearchGate, Zoom, Microsoft Teams, reference manager etc.) should lab members have personal accounts; what organisational accounts should they connect with on those services; are free upgrades available for students/academics; what resources are available for upgraded accounts

contents.title: Required skills
contents.description: hat skills do lab members require (e.g., experience with software used in the lab; see below); what resources are available for training/acquiring those skills; how should new members prioritise training vs other commitments

contents.title: Readings
contents.description: set of publications and/or resources that every lab member should have read to create a minimum common knowledge

contents.title: How to borrow equipment
contents.description: laptop, phone, desk, chair, screens etc.

contents.title: Using internal resources
contents.description: webpage, server, shared tools, room keys, coffee machine, books etc.

contents.title: Using external resources
contents.description: university/ building access card; institutional access to online resources; administrative assistants/ secretaries; access to printer/ photocopier/ printing card; VPN clients for working from home; remote desktop access, etc.

contents.title: Financial resources
contents.description: university relocation schemes, reimbursement for commuting, extra budget for buying a bike/ laptop/ office material etc.

contents.title: Resource to new foreign members
contents.description: helpful information on how to set up a life in the country/city (e.g., visa issues, registration at uni, opening bank accounts, tips on living in the country (renting flats, health insurance, student deals for using public transportations, etc.)

contents.title: Roles and duties of lab members
Roles
contents.description: describes the roles in the lab. What expectations and responsibilities come with each role

contents.title: Full members
contents.description: PI, postdocs, project managers, research assistants, master students, PhD students/candidates, etc.

contents.title: Associated members
contents.description: visiting students, collaborators

contents.title: Lab’s friends
contents.description: list of colleagues that are not part of the lab but that can be contacted because they are experts in topics that may be of interest (e.g. a colleague that is good in statistics or in programming, ongoing collaborations within the same or across different institutions, etc.

contents.title: Non-scientific members
contents.description: research coordinator, technicians, administrative assistants, etc.

contents.title: Duties and responsibilities
contents.description: general duties that will be assigned to lab members. e.g., organising lab meeting speakers, reserving conference room space, managing online (Zoom/Teams/GoogleMeet) meeting link, handling purchase orders, administering servers, handling lab social media, keeping the Lab Manual up-to-date

contents.title: Mentoring / career development
contents.description: expectations in a mentor-mentee relationship, professional development; performance evaluation

contents.title: Requesting letters of recommendation
contents.description: timeline for requesting; materials to provide with the request

contents.title: How to return equipment
contents.description: laptop, phone, etc.

contents.title: How to archive work
contents.description: paperwork, code, data, provide documentation of past work such that it can be picked up by others in the future

contents.title: Update/Revoke access
contents.description: update access to all apps, drives, accounts, etc.

contents.title: Keeping contact with ex-members
contents.description: e.g., new email address

contents.title: Annual structure
contents.description: How does a year look in the lab? How does term time differ from vacation time? What happens to lab meetings during summer break? Are there key annual events that require attendance?

contents.title: Leave/ holidays
contents.description: how many days of annual leave, is it okay to take most of your annual leave at once, sick leave guidelines, maternity leave, compassionate leave; how to request leave days/ whom to report leave to, e.g., administrative assistant/ official or PI; national holidays, special days on which the university is closed

contents.title: Lab hours
contents.description: when to be in the lab for different roles; when is the lab room open

contents.title: Absences
contents.description: when members are not in the lab, how to communicate leaves

contents.title: Weekly/ regular meetings
contents.description: time, place, Zoom/ Teams/ in-person, purpose, journal club readings + link to schedule

contents.title: Dealing with deadlines
contents.description: how to plan the completion of deadlines, how to deal with delays

contents.title: In-lab and remote working norms
contents.description: when are members expected to work in the lab or how can they work from home

contents.title: Calendar usage
contents.description: who to share your calendar with, what to put in your calendar

contents.title: Social and special events
contents.description: if lab dinners/ excursions/ team-building/ etc. is a part of lab life, or if it isn’t, mention it here, social events; suggestions for places for lunch

contents.title: Settling disagreements between lab members, “mediation”
contents.description: both between lab members, lab members, and outside scientists, lab members, and the PI

contents.title: Internal
contents.description: email accounts, how and when to use email, phone, texting, direct messaging, lab meetings, etc.; when are you expected to be available; what to do when one doesn’t respond; dealing with administration (e.g., try face-to-face), how to keep up the good mood, confidentiality questions beyond the lab, if you have a question: who to turn to?

contents.title: External
contents.description: social media policy, public outreach, independent mediators, how to get and give feedback

contents.title: Communication with collaborators
contents.description: communication with scientists outside the lab for work on common projects, e.g. keep the PI in ‘Cc’ or not, possible standard operating procedures to agree on/ negotiate before collaborating

contents.title: Visiting researchers
contents.description: Who to invite? How to invite? Accessing funds for visits etc.

contents.title: Lab vocabulary
contents.description: write a set of shared words by the lab members that are of everyday use (i.e., those words that are familiar to lab members but unfamiliar to newcomers, e.g., for tasks, effects, variables manipulated or measured)

contents.title: Taking guests
contents.description: where are guests allowed to access; when are guests permitted in the lab; who is allowed - visiting colleagues, family/friends, media/journalists; how many guests at a time (space/noise issues); safety of guests; hazards specific to the lab

contents.title: Lab social etiquette
contents.description: eating/drinking; noise control; dress-code

contents.title: Health & safety
contents.description: list of mandatory health and safety courses that lab members must follow; what to do in case of emergency; being sick/having mental health problems; how to find counselling, with links and information regarding university medical clinic and counselling centre

contents.title: Caring about happy lab life
contents.description: strategies for maintaining work-life balance and promoting well-being; recreational options at the workplace; helping each other; social time; being organised; boundary setting

contents.title: Starting a new project
contents.description: how to propose a new project; who can approve a study

contents.title: Creating the project team
contents.description: how to invite members; how to join a project; how to allocate the duties and tasks

contents.title: Logging the project
contents.description: creating a project repository

contents.title: Resources for starting studies
contents.description: financial resources, available equipment, available lab space, etc.

contents.title: Consultation
contents.description: literature review; expert consultation; focus groups

options.text: The study design is always discussed among lab members and local colleagues.
The design is discussed with other experts in the field using the expert consensus method, adversarial collaboration, presubmission inquiry, or registered report.

contents.title: Cross-checking
contents.description: protocol testing; materials testing; who are involved

options.text: At least one other lab member checks materials, experimental conditions for mistakes, and functionality issues (e.g., randomization for any test materials).
External researchers approached to check materials, experimental conditions for mistakes, and functionality issues (e.g., randomization for any test materials).

contents.title: Pilot testing
contents.description: when and how to conduct pilot tests; protocol testing; what to do with the results

options.text: We collect at least one set of test data for every protocol (i.e., experimental condition) and check the integrity of the data.

contents.title: Preregistering the study
contents.description: where/when to preregister; what should be in the preregistration, if applicable, links to template(s),  how to find past preregistrations from the lab

options.text: We publicly preregister every project before data collection following preregistration standards.

contents.title: Umbrella approval the lab has
contents.description: how to access those

contents.title: IRB ethics approval
contents.description: who is responsible; when and how to apply; where to document it; how to access applications for past projects in the lab

options.text: It is the project leader’s responsibility to make sure that IRB approval is obtained before any data collection. We share an English IRB approval document on our public project repository for each project.

contents.title: Other approvals
contents.description: e.g., from funder, collaborators

contents.title: Creating data management plan
contents.description: what should be in it; how often should it be refreshed

contents.title: Creating time management plan
contents.description: defining the milestones of a project; how to set time frames; project management tools; outlining the workflow; how to access plans for past projects in the lab

contents.title: Checking the calibration of hardware and tools
contents.description: e.g., check the calibration of measurement instruments and hardware equipment that will be used in the study; how to access standard operating procedures for past projects in the lab

contents.title: Preparing materials
contents.description: e.g., ordering supplies

contents.title: Creating the experiment
contents.description: tools and programs we use for experiment, with guidelines and links

contents.title: Securing testing space
contents.description: how to book the testing space; how to distribute testing space/slots; how to keep the testing space COVID-cautious

contents.title: Recruiting subjects
contents.description: how to recruit participants; how to compensate and administer participation; inclusion criteria to screen for; how to deliver instructions and check comprehension; how to deal with subject non-compliance

contents.title: Operating equipment
contents.description: who can use and how to use specialized equipment

contents.title: Collecting the data
contents.description: detailed instructions for in-lab, field and remote/online data collection; how to deal with equipment failure or medical emergencies; how to deal with incidental medical findings

contents.title: Securing protocol delivery
contents.description: checklists, supervision

contents.title: Documenting project development
contents.description: where do we log what happened (e.g., digital logbooks)

options.text: We document the major milestones that a project reaches in a text file that is shared with all the lab members.
We document project development publicly and continuously (e.g. on our webpage or through a public Github repository) throughout the lifecycle of the project.

contents.title: Closing data collection
contents.description: where to store paperwork; how to return equipment/ cancel lab bookings/ finalise finances; feedback for subjects (immediate/delayed, personal/public); writing report; list of operations to do when a study is concluded (e.g., final photo of the experimental setup, a short report of the study)

contents.title: Troubleshooting experiments
contents.description: how to force close software, name files to denote errors, re-runs, what to record for the data analyst

contents.title: Data processing and analysis
contents.description: what programs to use for data processing and analyses, how to document your work

options.text: The workflow of data processing is documented in detail and included in the manuscript.
Data processing is done by a reproducible, well-commented, human and machine-readable code (e.g. R-Markdown or Jupyter notebook).

contents.title: Data management quality control
contents.description: code review, code hygiene (keeping the code functional, commented, reproducible)

contents.title: Metadata
contents.description: e.g., using codebook, links to examples, tools for creating codebooks

options.text: Contains at least information about which project the data belongs to, when it was collected, and who collected it.
Contains time-stamped information on all the details of the project that the data belongs to (e.g., computer specifications, experimenter, etc.).

contents.title: Dataset structure
contents.description: what structure to prefer (e.g., tidy, long or wide); variable naming standards

contents.title: Folder structure
contents.description: e.g., different folders for raw and processed data; how to store data from different studies in the same project; standard folder structure for a project

contents.title: File and folder naming
contents.description: e.g., using snake or camel case

contents.title: File formats
contents.description: e.g., tsv for data files

contents.title: File version control
contents.description: e.g., using Git

contents.title: Saving and archiving
contents.description: when and where to store data for short and long term; where to store all the materials of a project (including approvals, signed consent forms, logs, data, analysis codes, etc.), backups

contents.title: Protection of data privacy
contents.description: how to ensure the safety of the collected personal information, safeguarding, and storing of primary data, who has access to the data

contents.title: Policies for sharing and access
contents.description: open data/ code/ materials; which repository to use; how to deal with errors detected at later stages; how to deal with different versions of the same code; sharing confidential documents

contents.title: Intellectual property and reuse
contents.description: what licence to use

options.text: Every graph, dataset, code analytic software, dataset, and study materials get licensed.

contents.title: Communicating the results of a study
Ensuring standard and transparent reporting
contents.description: choosing which guidelines to follow

contents.title: Templates/ standard operating procedures for plotting
contents.description: available code; PI preferences; consistent colour schemes; dealing with raw data/ plotting single data points

contents.title: Work-mode to co-write a paper
contents.description: Word documents sent back and forth, GoogleDocs, R Markdown/ papaya, Overleaf; Within lab folder of examples of well-written articles; reference management (e.g., zotero, mendeley, endnote)

contents.title: Proof-reading
contents.description: which documents to proof-read; who can you ask to proof-read

options.text: Co-authors should proofread any manuscript submissions, pre-prints, and conference presentation abstract submissions.

contents.title: Choosing the journal
contents.description: what are the main considerations for choosing a journal to publish our work

options.text: We developed a list of potential journals to publish in, based on considerations such as the relevance of the manuscript to the journal, journals that use the registered reports publishing format, publisher copyright and self-archiving policies (prioritised by the freedom to provide public access to pre-reviewed manuscripts).

contents.title: Contributorship
contents.description: when is contributorship decided; how to document it; what taxonomy to use (e.g., CRediT)

contents.title: Acknowledgments
contents.description: people, funding agencies

contents.title: Open access
contents.description: covering fees, preprint, specify the site(s) for posting preprints, postprints; how to make old papers easily available, is there an institutional repository

options.text: Whenever possible, we try to publish in open access journals. For all of our manuscripts, the latest version is openly shared as a preprint.

contents.title: Poster presentation
contents.description: how to access examples of lab posters at recent conferences, use logos from grant agency, university; where to print; using templates (e.g., #betterposter)

contents.title: Conference attendance
contents.description: which are standard conferences the lab attends regularly, who pays, are there extra opportunities to get money from the department/ university/ conference organiser, are there special internal criteria for attending, e.g. poster presentation/ talk etc.

contents.title: Talks
contents.description: presentation templates; how to give a talk; how to access slides of past talks given by lab members; how to acknowledge other lab members and funding agencies

contents.title: Public engagement
contents.description: using social media such as Twitter; blogpost; public talks

contents.title: How to deal with mistakes
contents.description: how to detect mistakes, how to decrease damage, how to learn from mistakes and prevent them in the future, who should be talked to first, is there a designated lab member before talking to the PI; is there a university official to report serious errors/ accidents to

contents.title: Confidentiality breaches
contents.description: e.g., data breaches; whom to report to

contents.title: Lab money
contents.description: what does the lab/faculty cover and how

contents.title: Scholarships, travel grants, prizes and awards for student members
contents.description: list possibilities for student with links, modes to get the applications of other lab members who won before

contents.title: Grant, scholarship administration
contents.description: where to log, how to log administration, are there grant officers to assist with grant writing; how budgets are proposed in funding applications; who gets to participate in funding applications

contents.title: University benefits/ discounts
contents.description: e.g. discounts for health insurance, gym membership, book sales
